targets.expr:
max by(type) (label_replace(qbittorrent_global_max_active_downloads{instance="$instance"}, "type", "download", "invalid", ""))
or
max by(type) (label_replace(qbittorrent_global_max_active_uploads{instance="$instance"}, "type", "upload", "invalid", ""))
or
max by(type) (label_replace(qbittorrent_global_max_active_torrents{instance="$instance"}, "type", "total", "invalid", ""))

options.content:
qbittorrent has 3 ways of reporting speed:

1. Instantaneous speed, shown in the footer in webUI.
It fluctuates a lot, and it isn't really useful.
Prometheus scrapes data once every N seconds. It can be that your speed is 10 MiB/s on average,
but rigth before the scrape the speed increased to 20 MiB/s. And before next scrape it increased to 15 MiB/s.
You would think that the average is 15+ MiB/s.

2. Logical speed.
qbittorrent reports how many data bytes it has transferred.
You can then get average speed as `delta_bytes / delta_time`.
The result is less detailed, but it's mathematically accurate.
Only actual transferred data blocks are counted.

3. Real speed. Similar to logical speed, but protocol overhead is now counted.
It is always bigger than logical speed.
Even if all torents are finished, but you are seeding some torrents,
you will see non-zero download speed
because you are exchanging metadata with other peers.
